Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello 16, 80131 - Napoli, Italy;

of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China;
INAF - Osservatorio Astronomico di Padova, via dell’Osservatorio
Peng Cheng Laboratory, No.2, Xingke 1st Street, Shenzhen, 518000, P. R. China
Toward a stellar population catalog in the Kilo Degree Survey: the
impact of stellar recipes on stellar masses and star formation rates
School of Physics and Astronomy, Sun Yat-sen University, Zhuhai Campus, 2 Daxue Road, Xiangzhou District, Zhuhai, P. R. China;;
Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Anqing Normal University, Anqing, Anhui 246133, China;
Yunnan Observatories, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Kunming, 650011, Yunnan, People’s Republic of China;
National Astronomical Observatories, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 20A Datun Road, Chaoyang District, Beijing 100012, China;
INAF - Osservatorio Astronomico di Arcetri, Largo Enrico Fermi 5, 50125, Firenze, Italy;
School of Physics and Astronomy, China West Normal University, ShiDa Road 1, 637002, Nanchong, China
The Kilo Degree Survey (KiDS) is currently the only sky survey providing optical (
matched photometry over an area larger than 1000
. This is obtained by incorporating the NIR data from the VISTA Kilo
Degree Infrared Galaxy (VIKING) survey, covering the same KiDS footprint. As such, the KiDS multi-wavelength photometry
represents a unique dataset to test the ability of stellar population models to return robust photometric stellar mass (

represents a unique dataset to test the ability of stellar population models to return robust photometric stellar mass (M∗) and starformation rate (SFR) estimates. Here we use a spectroscopic sample of galaxies for which we possess ugriZYJHKs “gaussianized”
magnitudes from KiDS data release 4. We fit the spectral energy distribution from the 9-band photometry using: 1) three di
popular libraries of stellar population templates, 2) single burst, simple and delayed exponential star-formation history models, and
3) a wide range of priors on age and metallicity. As template fitting codes we use two popular softwares: LePhare and CIGALE.
We investigate the variance of the stellar masses and the star-formation rates from the di
formation recipes and codes to assess the stability of these estimates and define some “robust” median quantities to be included
in the upcoming KiDS data releases. As a science validation test, we derive the mass function, the star formation rate function,
) sample of galaxies, that result in excellent agreement with previous literature
Characteristics and properties of external galaxies – Stellar content and populations; Origin, formation, evolution, age,
and star formation; Masses and mass distribution
Science China Press and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2017
, et al. Sci. China-Phys. Mech. Astron.
The spectral energy distribution (SED) of galaxies provides crucial information on the properties of their stellar populations
erent cosmic epochs. In particular, the stellar mass content and the star formation history of galaxies are of major
importance to understand the mechanisms of their formation, including the impact of the environment on their properties [e.g.,
]. For instance, the study of the stellar mass function as a function of the redshift is a crucial probe of the stellar mass assembly
], and combined with the halo mass function of simulations, can be used as a cosmological probe, e.g. in
]). Similarly, the star formation rate function can measure the growth of the stellar
content of galaxies across the cosmic time (e.g. [
]). A relevant example of scaling relation is the star formation versus stellar
mass, also known as the galaxy main sequence ([
]). This is crucial to understand the formation mechanisms
of galaxies, in particular the relation between the star formation activity across time ([
The measurement of the galaxy stellar masses and star formation rates mainly relies on details of stellar population analyses
]), and their ability to constrain the stellar mass-to-light ratios (e.g. [
This is a notoriously complex problem ([
]), due to the existence of degeneracies among some of the parameters, in particular
]). Furthermore, in order to convert the stellar population parameters into
“galaxy” properties, one needs to account for the galaxy intrinsic luminosity, which carries other uncertainties, e.g. galaxy
distances, or redshifts. This step is generally incorporated in the stellar population codes that can model the SED using the
]) or as an input from spectra or photo-z codes (e.g. [
routinely used to derive stellar masses, age, metallicity using simple stellar population (SSP, e.g. [
population models with a parametrized star formation history (SFH, e.g. delayed exponential: [
Optical broadband photometry alone cannot break the dust-age–metallicity degeneracies (e.g. [
wavelength range in the near-infrared (NIR) can provide additional constraints that can alleviate them ([
combination of optical and NIR photometry is also e
ective for photometric redshifts from SED fitting techniques, which are
an important ingredient in stellar population analyses. These consist of finding a model galaxy spectrum, given by a linear
combination of representative stellar or galaxy templates, which best fits the observed galaxy SED ([
wide baseline can alleviate the degeneracy between various galaxy spectra as a function of galaxy redshifts ([
In this paper, we want to test the outcomes of di
erent stellar population codes, namely LePhare ([
erent stellar population templates and star formation histories, using a multi-band, seeing matched catalog of galaxies
collected in the fourth data release (DR4) of the Kilo Degree Survey (KiDS, [
for which we possess 1) optical photometry in
bands from the VISTA Kilo Degree
photometric redshifts. It collects about 290 000 sources, a subsample of which has already been used in KiDS to calibrate
]). The advantage of spectroscopic redshifts is that they alleviate the degeneracies between
colors and redshifts, which further impact the accuracy of the stellar parameters. The addition of photometric redshifts will
also allow us to assess the impact of their larger uncertainties on the same stellar parameters. In fact,
the final goal of this work
is to evaluate the variance of the stellar population quantities from di
erent SED fitting recipes, popular stellar population
templates, as well as the uncertainties on redshifts.
We will determine what are the most stable parameters and define robust
quantities suitable for science applications. This is a first step to define a strategy to produce a robust stellar population catalog
for the upcoming KiDS data release 5 (KiDS-DR5, Wright et al. 2023). The main parameters we are interested in are the stellar
mass and the star formation rate, but we will also provide the catalog of ages and metallicities of the galaxy stellar populations
from a large set of priors. Since for this spectroscopic sample we also possess very accurate morphotometric redshifts from
]), we can finally test the impact of redshifts derived from pure multi-band photometric catalogs
combining optical and NIR, like the ones expected to be collected from future large sky surveys like Euclid mission ([
Rubin Legacy Survey in Space and Time (VR
There have been previous works including stellar population analyses of KiDS galaxy catalogs, either determining stellar
mass only, for weak lensing studies ([
]) or estimating galaxy properties, including photometric redshifts and stellar masses,
]), or estimating structural parameters and stellar mass to select ultra-compact and massive
, et al. Sci. China-Phys. Mech. Astron.
]) and for central dark matter studies ([
]). However, none of these has investigated the impact on the stellar
masses of the combination of fitting procedure and stellar templates. A similar analysis has been provided for the CANDELS
]), where they used optical plus NIR photometry and tested the impact on stellar masses of di
codes, stellar templates and star formation histories.
As a science validation test, we will conclude our analysis by using stellar mass and star formation rate estimates to derive
the stellar mass function, the star formation rate function, and the mass vs. star formation rate relation of the galaxies from
the KiDS spectroscopic sample, using both spectroscopic and deep learning redshifts and compare them with literature data at
The paper is organised as follow. In Sect.
we introduce the data and the set-up of the stellar population analysis; in Sect.
we present the stellar population inferences, assess their accuracy and precision using a series of statistical estimators, and define
a robust definition of the stellar mass and star formation estimates; in Sect.
we discuss the dependence of the accuracy and
scatter on galaxy properties and finally show the galaxy mass function, the star formation rate function, and the stellar mass-star
formation rate relation as a science validation test; in Sect.
we draw some conclusions and perspectives for future analyses.
Throughout the paper, we will adopt the following cosmological parameters:
The spectroscopic sample which we use in this paper consists of 9-band photometry from the 1000 deg
19), plus spectroscopic redshifts collected from the Galaxy Mass Assembly [GAMA,
] survey, and the Sloan Digital Sky Survey
the KiDS footprint. We also add further machine learning redshifts from the GaZNet convolutional network presented in [
as these have been demonstrated to provide very accurate redshifts up to
In the following we describe in more details the content of the dataset and the di
erent stellar population model set-ups used to
The photometric data of the spectroscopic sample are collected from the KiDS and the VIKING surveys. These are two sister
bands, respectively. The KiDS survey has been
]). It has been optimized for weak lensing in the
band, which provides best seeing imaging (average FWHM
. The other bands have been observed with poorer seeing and reached mean limiting AB magnitudes of
VIKING has been carried out at the VISTA
]) and complemented KiDS observations with five NIR bands
s). The median value of the seeing is
]), and the AB magnitude depths are 23.1, 22.3, 22.1, 21.5 and
The 9-band fluxes have been measured via the Gaussian Aperture and PSF (GAaP) photometry method ([
colours that are corrected for PSF di
erences. Hence, GAaP photometry naturally provides seeing matched fluxes for each
source in the catalog, by definition. However, sources more extended than the aperture function result in underestimated total
fluxes. In order to correct this systematic e
ect, a total aperture correction needs to be applied to derive the “total” galaxy
19 the GAaP photometry is Galactic extinction corrected using the [
As a spectroscopic database, we have collected redshifts from: 1) GAMA data release 4 ([
], SDSS-DR17 hereafter). Previous compilations of spectroscopic data overlapping with the KiDS area did not include
SDSS-DR17, but included other high redshift datasets (see e.g. [
] and reference therein). However, the statistics of galaxies
matching the KiDS-DR4 catalog at redshift larger than
is rather sparse. On the other hand, for the analysis we are
interested to perform in this paper, SDSS-DR17 and GAMA provide a quite abundant sample of galaxies at
GAMA is the most complete sample, reaching
To match the redshift distributions of the two catalogs, we exclude sources at
, where the overall catalog drops to
a constant number of a few tens of galaxies per redshift bin, mainly from SDSS-DR17. We also notice that a large portion
are classified as “stars” from their parent surveys. Hence, to avoid the contamination from other
, et al. Sci. China-Phys. Mech. Astron.
Properties of the spectroscopic sample. Left: the distribution of the final selected “galaxy” sample (see text for details), separated in the di
-band MAG AUTO from the KiDS-DR4 catalog.
misclassified stars, we decide to use a conservative cut and select only sources with
classified as Quasars (QSO), as their SED might be dominated by the nuclei emission, rather than the stellar population light.
These criteria together produce a final catalog of 242678 GAMA and 77859 SDSS-DR17 galaxies, which includes 31728
repeated sources. For these duplicates, we adopt the SDSS-DR17 redshifts, which have errors, finally ending up with a total
of 288 809 objects. In the following, we consider these sources to be “galaxies”, although we might still expect some minor
contamination from unclassified QSO (or active galactic nuclei, AGN).

however we will need to consider this when the stellar parameters will be used for the science validation test (see Sect.

LePhare stellar population: set-up and templates
]), is a template-fitting code, which performs a simple
minimization between the stellar population synthesis
(SPS) theoretical models and data, in a standard cosmology (see §
). In our analysis we adopt a [
] dust-extinction law. We also include the contribution of nebular emission, e.g. from low-mass starforming
): LePhare uses a simple recipe based on the Kennicutt relations [
] between the SFR and UV luminosity,
and [OII] lines. Regarding the stellar templates, we test three di
, CB07 hereafter] stellar population synthesis (SPS) models. We have also adopted three
erent models for the star formation history (SFH),
1) In LePhare, there is no real option to set the IMF, but this is implemented in the stellar libraries. For the [
] libraries the IMF closer to Chabrier is the
] IMF. To account for these IMF di
erence we will simply adopt the standard -0.05 dex correction to transform Kroupa-based into Chabrier-based masses.
, et al. Sci. China-Phys. Mech. Astron.
Summary of the set-ups adopted for the stellar population models

. 2: Initial Mass Function: note that we have converted the stellar masses from the Kroupa IMF to the Chabrier

Delayed exponential. Row 5: characteristic decaying time, as defined in Sects.
7: age range and steps. Note that the age cannot exceed the age of the universe at each redshift. Row 8: whether or not nebular lines are included in the model.
Row 9: internal extinction law adopted. Row 10: the extinction values adopted in the models for the Calzetti law.
age of the galaxy, 2) the exponentially declining law (ExD, hereafter),
, and finally 3) a combination of both
ExD), which is directly allowed by, e.g., the M05 stellar libraries. We remark here that the choice of the exponential
declining SFH is due to the limited choice o
ered by Le Phare, even though the ExD is flexible enough to embrace a variety of
realistic SFHs. CIGALE (see below) will give us the chance to make a di
erent choice, although a more general approach with
a larger variety of SFHs will be considered in future analyses. The full LePhare set-up is summarized in Table
, we use the redshift, both spec-

best-fit parameters as a reference for this analysis.
CIGALE stellar population: set-up and templates
We also adopt the Code Investigating GALaxy Emission (CIGALE, [
], v2020.0), which can construct the FUV to the radio
SEDs of galaxies and provide star formation rate, attenuation, dust luminosity, stellar mass, and many other physical quantities,
using composite stellar populations from simple stellar populations combined with highly flexible star formation histories. For
our analysis, we make use of BC03 and M05 stellar templates. Di
erently from LePhare, CIGALE does not have a pure ExD
law among the SFH choices, hence we decide to adopt a delayed exponential law (DelEx, hereafter),
which is smoother than the exponential declining SFH from LePhare. Consistently with LePhare, we have adopted a [
] dust-extinction law and both the inclusion or not of nebular continuum and emission lines for the
BC03 only. In CIGALE the nebular templates adopted are based on [
]. The full set-up parameters, including the range of

. As for LePhare, we use the best-fit parameters from CIGALE in the

erent SFHs on the stellar masses and SFR estimates. The SFH models above have have been e

] and cosmic SFR density and stellar mass density at redshifts
]. As anticipated, we also include the e
ect of emission lines that, although they are generally important
in massive galaxies at high redshift (e.g.[

ects. Moreover, as we are preparing the methods to be applied to the full KiDS photometric dataset,

ered by the spectroscopic “galaxy” sample (e.g. down to
22). This will allow us to evaluate the
existence or not of systematics on stellar population parameters, and the impact on the precision of the estimates, due to the
usage of the more scattered photometric redshifts. Once collected all the estimates from all the configurations in Table
will 1) check the overall consistency among the di
erent stellar parameters; 2) discuss the scatter of the parameters and possibly
define some robust estimator for them. As mentioned in the Sect.
, in this first paper we concentrate on the stellar masses
and the star formation rates, as the most physical meaningful parameters one can extract from large multi-band photometric
samples of galaxies, to study their evolution across the cosmic time. We use the estimates from BC03 templates and ExD
as reference model for mass and star formation estimates
otherwise specified. This is for uniformity with previous analyses in KiDS (e.g. [
among the stellar mass and the SFR estimates among the di
erent configurations, we will use the following estimators: 1) the
relative bias, 2) the median absolute error and 3) the outlier fraction, defined in Sect.
In this section we show the results for the stellar masses for the case we fix the redshift of the galaxies of the sample to the
spectroscopic and morphoto-metric redshifts, introduced in Sect.
. By stellar masses, we aim at
determining the total mass in stars, while we have seen in Sect.
that the seeing matched GAaP photometry adopted in KiDS
does not correspond to a “total aperture”. Hence, if using these fractional fluxes, the stellar masses calculated by the stellar
population codes are the mass of stars required to produce the inputted galaxy SED, resulting in an aperture bias. Therefore,
in order to recover a fair estimate of the total galaxy stellar mass, the observed SED must be representative of the total light
emitted from the galaxy. In order to correct this systematic e
ect, we opt to use the quasi-total SExtractor, MAG AUTO, using
is the stellar mass estimated by the stellar population tools, GAAP r is the
is the corrected “total” mass, under the assumption of constant mass-to-light ratios. In the
following we will first show the results of the stellar population analysis using the spectroscopic redshift, then we compare
these latters with the results of the morphoto-
to estimate the impact of the larger uncertainties on these latter on determining
). Finally, we discuss the impact of the inclusion of the nebular emissions in the models.

3.1.3 The impact of the nebular emissions on stellar masses
As anticipated at the beginning of Sect.
, we intend to check the impact of the inclusion of nebular emission on our models.
are all sparsely distributed in the optical and NIR wavelength at redshift
, but they are generally fainter than the continuum
collected by the broad bands in this redshift range, except for strong starburst, low-mass galaxies. Here, we have the chance
to estimate the impact of the presence of these emissions on the stellar masses, while we will discuss the impact on the star
ered by the LePhare and CIGALE (see details in Sects.
) to implement the NE in the models as in Table
. The results of the statistical estimators are reported in Table
between brackets, for all models considered. Here, we do not find any significant variation of the indicators of all models, which
lets us to conclude that the stellar masses are poorly sensitive to the inclusion of the NE, regardless the stellar template, the SFH
and the code adopted. We will keep the record of these models in the catalog and we will consider the for the discussion on the
variance of the models in the discussion (Sect.
In this section, we present the results on the star formation rates. These measurements represent the current amount of stellar
masses formed per unit of time corresponding to the best parameters of the assumed SFH model fitting the SED. As, by
definition, the single burst models do not provide any such estimate, they will be discarded in the following analysis. For the
same reason, the mixed model allowed from the M05 libraries (SB
ExD) is almost equivalent to the ExD, as it returns the same
SFR estimates for the galaxies best fitted with an exponential SFH (ExD). Hence, only the latter one will be listed in the result
tables and figures for the LePhare models, together with the DelEx of CIGALE.
We remind here the set of
and ages adopted for the models in Table
. As seen, we have used a rather large sample of both
parameters to check the impact of them on our inferences, even though some extreme values can be either slightly un-physical
or too optimistic. For instance, there might be little sensitivity from the fitting procedure to e
Gyr and 30 Gyr, both producing rather flat SFH, hence leaving a large leverage to the model to converge on both values
with similar confidence. On the other hand, the stellar models can be rather insensitive to an
band photometry unable to catch the typical feature of young stars, and also given the very shallow limiting magnitude of the
-band that would provide most of the UV rest-frame emission of galaxies up to
. However, for this test we decide to
maintain a broad range of priors for the parameter space to learn their impact and confidently optimize their choice for future
As far as the output of both stellar population codes is concerned, similarly to stellar masses in Sect.
should also be corrected for the total fluxes. This is needed to ensure that the specific star formation rate,
a galaxy is conserved. Hence, in the following, we will correct the SFRs by the same amount of the stellar masses, i.e.
are the output of the SED fitting codes and
Finally, as we want to select a star-forming sample, we will adopt a canonical cut in specific star formation rate (sSFR) to
separate passive from active galaxies and use
]). SSFRs lower than this value should not be taken, in principle, at face value as these correspond to a physically negligible
SFR. For this reason, we do not use them in our analysis, although we report them in our catalog with the warning to use them
As for the stellar masses in Sect.
, we first discuss the SFR results obtained using the spectroscopic redshift as fixed
parameter in LePhare and CIGALE. In Fig.
, we show the SFRs computed using the di
erent libraries and SFHs as in Table

To conclude the analysis of the SFRs we can say that, as for the stellar masses, these are also a rather stable quantities with
respect to the fitting tool, stellar libraries and SFHs, as they do not show significant systematics, except for small SFRs, although
we register a tendency of the M05 models to underestimate the SFRs with respect to the BC03.

Some considerations about other sources of systematics
Before moving to some science application we need to stress that providing a full insight into all possible systematics that might
come from the stellar population analysis is beyond the purpose of this paper.
We have already introduced the problem of the wavelength coverage in Sect.

Finally, a comment on the stellar templates. In this paper we have used a variety of libraries that could be directly incorporated
in the two reference tools adopted (see Table
). However, this list is neither complete, nor optimal to really account for the
current state-of-art stellar population models. We expect to expand our analysis to other stellar libraries (see, e.g., MILES,
]), in future analyses. In this respect, we can consider this analysis as a first step to a more general program to implement
a larger variety of models to ground based multi-band datasets.

In this paper we have used a spectroscopic galaxy catalog including 9-band (
release of the Kilo-Degree Survey (KiDS) to derive robust stellar masses and star formation histories. We have performed a
full template fitting analysis using two popular stellar population codes, LePhare and CIGALE, and a combination of stellar
]) and star formation histories (i.e. a single burst, an exponential decline, and a delayed
exponential). Besides the spectroscopic redshifts, taken from GAMA data releases 2 and 3 and SDSS data release 17, we have
considered as input of the SED fitting process, the morphoto-metric redshifts obtained from the deep learning tool GaZNet
]). In this latter case, we can perform a controlled test of the variance one would introduce, in large dataset, where only
photometric redshift are available for the galaxy catalogs.
In fact, the main goal of this analysis has been to assess the relative accuracy and the variance of the stellar population
parameters under a variety of combinations of fitting tools
star formation histories. We summarize here below
the main result of this analysis:
1) the stellar mass and the star formation rate show limited scatter and relative bias which is within the scatter, when comparing the estimates for every galaxies against the di
erent methods. As such, these quantities are rather stable against the stellar
2) the relative bias, NMAD and outlier fraction vary with the stellar mass and SNR, not with redshift;
3) due to the overall resilience of the parameters to the di
erent variables in play, we can reasonably adopt a median definition
as an unbiased estimator of the “ground truth” values for the parameters. Following [
median for this robust parameter estimate and used them for a science validation;
4) we have evaluated the scatter of the individual fitting set-ups with respect to the Hodges-Lehmann median (Fig.
found that, depending on the combination of templates and star formation histories, stellar masses and star formation rates can
0.1 dex, for high mass systems, to
5) as a science validation test, we have derived the stellar mass function and the star formation rate mass function, as well as
relation and compared with previous literature in dif
erent redshift bins, finding a very good match with a wide
6) we provide the catalog of the galaxy parameters, including stellar masses, star formation rates, age, metallicity, extinction
of the exponential decaying models, for
GAMA and SDSS-DR17. The catalog is available at this URL
and contains also the 9-band GAaP photometry, the
MAG AUTO, and the spectroscopic redshift from the parent spectroscopic surveys.
In the future we plan to expand this test, including more stellar formation tools (e.g. FAST : [
This will allow us to investigate an even larger variety of models and use the “median” of their outcomes (see Sect.
as an unbiased stellar population parameter estimators for the full KiDS “galaxy” photometric sample and finally provide a
general-purpose catalog to be used for a variety of galaxy studies. Piece of similar datasets have been previously used in KiDS,
